column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2

#Text=[0056]Briefly, the method step 204 for computing the autocorrelation from the preambles and pilots can be achieved by computing a first autocorrelation from the preambles in parallel with computing a second autocorrelation from the pilots.

#Text=Notably, the method step 204, uses a product of a preamble fading estimate and a pilot fading estimate that is averaged over a plurality of frames that is independent of pilot structure for computing the autocorrelation.
#Text=A first method 300 for computing a first portion of the autocorrelation from only the preambles is presented in FIG. 8.
#Text=A second method 400 for computing a second portion of the autocorrelation from the preambles and pilots is presented in FIG. 11.
#Text=[0057]Referring to FIG. 8, a method 300 for computing the autocorrelation from only the preambles is shown.
#Text=The method 300 can be practiced with more or less than the number of steps shown.

#Text=To describe the method 300, reference will be made to FIGS. 2 and 9 although it is understood that the method 300 can be implemented in any other suitable device or system using other suitable components.
#Text=Moreover, the method 300 is not limited to the order in which the steps are listed in the method 300.
#Text=[0058]At step 301, the method 300 can start.
#Text=As an example, in the context of IEEE 802.16 frame parameters and values, a sampling time of 5 ms can be used, which gives a sampling rate of 200 Hz.
#Text=Accordingly, the maximum Doppler frequency that can be reliably detected is 100 Hz; that is, half the sampling frequency based on the Nyquist theorem.
#Text=If a carrier frequency of 2.5 GHz for the communication signal is used, a vehicle speed of 41 km/hr using EQ (2) can be determined.
#Text=Briefly referring to FIG. 9, an illustration of the preambles 120 for multiply received frames is shown.
#Text=The sampling time of 5 ms corresponds to the frame time interval for each preamble 120.
#Text=That is, every 5 ms a frame (102) containing a downlink portion (111) is received (See FIG. 2).
#Text=Only the preamble 120 are shown in FIG. 9, as the method 300 is based only on using information in the preamble 120 to estimate a first autocorrelation, R.sub.PR(.tau.).
#Text=Note the "PR" in the subscript refers to the use of Preambles only in this method, in contrast to "PI" which will be used in the Preambles-plus-pilots method later.
#Text=During the Preamble symbol time, a known sequence is transmitted on every third sub-carrier 144, excluding the guard-bands.
#Text=For an FFT size of 512, this amounts to 143 sub-carriers as illustrated in FIG. 5.
#Text=To keep complexity and storage low, only a subset of the 143 Preamble sub-carriers will be used.
#Text=Those used will be spread across the frequency band uniformly, spaced apart by .DELTA.F.sub.SC,PR sub-carriers.
#Text=The lowest value possible for .DELTA.F.sub.SC,PR is 3, because every third sub-carrier is used in Preamble transmission.
#Text=However, much higher values, up to 30, can be used with negligible effect on performance and substantial benefit in complexity and storage.
#Text=The fading estimates (channel estimates) on the subset of Preamble sub-carriers will be stored over a window of N.sub.PR frames.
#Text=During each frame, an estimate of R.sub.PR(.tau.) will be formed, and the Doppler estimated according to EQ 3 above.

#Text=[0059]At step 302, a fading estimate can be formed for each subcarrier of a specified subset of subcarriers of the preamble over a number of symbol intervals based on a received preamble and a known transmitted preamble.
#Text=Briefly, referring to FIG. 9: [0060]a.
#Text=For the jth sub-carrier (144) of the subset, form the fading estimate
#Text=[0060] H j ( i ) = Y j ( i ) X j ( i ) [0061]where Y.sub.j(i) and X.sub.j(i) are the received and transmitted signals, respectively, in the ith symbol interval. [0062]b.
#Text=Store the current fading estimate, to form a window of N.sub.PR fading estimates, spaced apart in time by 5 ms:
